perturbation.original_text: 3.2.3. "Gross Revenues" means all revenue from the sale of all services and products and all other income of every kind and nature related to, derived from, or originating from the Franchised Business, including proceeds of any business interruption insurance policies, whether for cash or credit, and regardless of collection in the case of credit; provided, however, that "Gross Revenues" does not include any coupon sales (for which customers do not pay for product), customer refunds, sales taxes or other taxes you collected from customers and actually transmitted to the appropriate taxing authorities.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.2.3. "Gross Revenues" means most revenue from the sale of all services and products and most other income of every kind and nature related to, derived from, or originating from the Franchised Business, including proceeds of any business interruption insurance policies, whether for cash or credit, and regardless of collection in the case of credit; provided, however, that "Gross Revenues" may not include any coupon sales (for which customers do not pay for product), customer refunds, sales taxes or other taxes you collected from customers and actually transmitted to the appropriate taxing authorities.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Gross Revenues' is comprehensive and clearly defined what is included and excluded. By changing 'all revenue' to 'most revenue' and 'does not include' to 'may not include', the definition becomes ambiguous and gives the franchisee potential leeway to interpret what constitutes Gross Revenue, leading to potential disputes and underreporting, conflicting with standard accounting practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and standard franchise law requiring clear financial reporting.

perturbation.original_text: 6.5. Delivery Vehicles. If you wish to use a vehicle to provide delivery services (a "Delivery Vehicle") as part of your Franchised Business, you must comply with the specifications and standards that we may periodically prescribe in the Manuals for Delivery Vehicles. Our specifications and standards may include, among other things: designating Delivery Vehicles specific make and model; limitations on the Useful Life for a Delivery Vehicle and standards for maintenance or repair services.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.5. Delivery Vehicles. If you wish to use a vehicle to provide delivery services (a "Delivery Vehicle") as part of your Franchised Business, you must attempt to comply with the suggestions and standards that we may periodically suggest in the Manuals for Delivery Vehicles. Our suggestions and standards may include, among other things: Delivery Vehicles general make and model; general statements on the Life for a Delivery Vehicle and non-binding maintenance or repair services.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates compliance with specific standards for delivery vehicles. By softening the language to 'attempt to comply' and changing 'specifications and standards' to 'suggestions and standards', the franchisee's obligation becomes unclear and less enforceable. Also, changing 'designating Delivery Vehicles specific make and model; limitations on the Useful Life for a Delivery Vehicle and standards for maintenance or repair services' to 'Delivery Vehicles general make and model; general statements on the Life for a Delivery Vehicle and non-binding maintenance or repair services.' conflicts with general safety and branding regulations for vehicle standards.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Motor Vehicle Safety Standards and potential violations of brand uniformity laws.

perturbation.original_text: 17.2. After Termination, Expiration, or Transfer. For two (2) years after the expiration or termination of this Agreement or an approved Transfer to a new franchisee, you may not directly or indirectly own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within three (3) mile radius of the Premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Restaurant then-operating or under construction to operate under the System, except as permitted by any Franchise Agreements that remain in effect between you and us.
perturbation.changed_text: 17.2. After Termination, Expiration, or Transfer. For potentially two (2) years after the potential expiration or termination of this Agreement or a Transfer to a new franchisee, you are potentially restricted from directly or indirectly owning, managing, engaging in, being employed by, advising, making loans to, consulting for, or having any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within three (3) mile radius of the Premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Restaurant then-operating or under construction to operate under the System, except as potentially permitted by Franchise Agreements.
perturbation.explanation: The original non-compete clause is clearly defined with a fixed term and radius. By adding the word 'potentially,' the restrictions become uncertain and difficult to enforce. This change could be interpreted as weakening the non-compete agreement, which might conflict with the franchisor's interests and potentially be challenged under laws governing non-compete enforceability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State laws governing the enforceability of non-compete agreements.
